desc: Ahousaht School opened in 1904 by the Women’s Missionary Society
In May of 1917 the Ahousaht Boarding School burnt down
A roof fire occurred in the classroom on May 7th, 1931

The main school building was destroyed by fire on January 26th, 1940. All students were returned to their homes.It was recommended that a temporary day school be opened at Ahousaht to care for the education needs of 40 pupils whose homes were located in Ahousaht.

religiousGroups.group: Women's Missionary Society of the United Church

writtenAgreements.desc: Agreement between His Majesty the King and the Secretary of the Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada to support, maintain and educate, in a manner satisfactory to the Superintendent General, at the boarding school at Ahousaht in the province of British Columbia … not more than Twenty-five (25) Indian pupils.

additionalInformation.notes: A document refers to complaints being made against the Principal of the Ahousaht Boarding School. No details are provided as to the nature of the complaints.
In 1915, an unfortunate accident involving matches caused the death of a student at the school.
In 1915/1916, there was a death at the school.
During the 1927/1928 school year, two pupils passed away.
In 1938, an accident in the laundry room of the school caused a student to have an arm injury that required amputation.
In 1938-39, the school was described as a sanitation and fire hazard and a recommendation was made that it be abandoned at the earliest possible date.

During the 1905/1906 school year, an epidemic of whooping-cough and grippe passed through the school. An isolation room was used for any serious or contagious conditions and one of the staff was a trained nurse.
During the 1906/1907 school year, some sickness was experienced from an epidemic of grippe. During the year, one boy died at the school.

During the 1907/1908 school year there was an epidemic of measles in February; one girl, whose health had not been good for some time previously, died a coupleof weeks after her recovery from the measles. One boy died in December from tubercular trouble. The school had a suitable room provided for isolation in cases of sickness.

During the 1908/1909 school year, there was 'an epidemic of measles at the close of the last year'. One girl died from complications resulting from the disease and one boy died from tubercular trouble. Two pupils were dismissed on account of their health being unsatisfactory for school life.
During the 1909/1910 school year, two girls were discharged on account of their health being unsatisfactory for school life. One of the girls discharged died from consumption.
One pupil, who was discharged in 1911, died in August of 1912.
During the 1912/1913 school year, there was one slight epidemic of grippe during the winter.
During the 1912/1913 school year, an ex-pupil, discharged a year ago in January, died from consumption in July.

During the 1915/1916 school year, there was one slight epidemic among children of Ahousaht in January, which, at first was thought to be small-pox, but fortunately did not develop into anything more serious than chicken-pox.
During the 1926/1927 school year, a serious epidemic of flu disorganized the routine of the school.
During the 1935/1936 school year, a female pupil was discharged from the school with incurable tuberculosis.
During November of 1938, thirty-two children were confined to bed with influenza and tonsillitis, which appeared to be found throughout the school.
During May of 1939, children were recovering from influenza.
